question: A 5d² double perovskite has U ≈ 4 eV, hopping t ≈ 0.05 eV (bandwidth ≈ 0.3 eV, so U/t≈80) but the B′–B′ spacing of 6.6 Å reduces the kinetic superexchange to J_SE ≈ 0.1 meV—ten times smaller than the 1 meV classical dipole–dipole interaction between 1 µB moments. gold_trace:
Although U≫bandwidth satisfies the Mott condition, the cause ‘virtual hopping generates significant multipolar superexchange’ is numerically tiny (0.1 meV) compared with dipolar dipole–dipole terms.  The observed order is dipolar and conventional, contradicting the prediction that higher-rank multipolar IEIs dominate.  Therefore agreement is very weak.
strong U suppresses charge fluctuations → superexchange becomes leading coupling (but magnitude tiny)

question: For J_eff = 3/2 ions on an fcc lattice, virtual hopping yields a quadrupole–quadrupole coupling V₂₂ ≈ 3 meV but a stronger dipolar Heisenberg term V₁₁ ≈ 12 meV. Here the dipolar term is four times larger and dictates the Néel state; multipolar order is negligible.  While the formal projection step exists, the crucial cause ‘multipolar IEI dominate’ is not met, so consistency is low.
symmetry of GSM → projection onto multipoles (valid)
virtual hopping → IEI matrix with V₂₂ (3 meV) & V₁₁ (12 meV)

Here, however, the dominant exchange is clearly dipolar (V₁₁ ≈ 12 meV versus V₂₂ ≈ 3 meV) and mean-field theory finds a simple Néel state with negligible higher-rank order. question: In a Jahn–Teller-active d¹ compound the linear coupling is g_JT ≈ 0 ± 0.5 meV Å⁻¹, while electronic quadrupole–quadrupole superexchange is ≈ 2 meV. gold_trace:
Contract 10-2 relies on a non-zero g_JT to couple even-parity multipoles to lattice modes and predicts sizeable concomitant distortions at the multipolar transition.  Here g_JT is essentially zero and the minute distortion occurs only after magnetic order, indicating lattice coupling is negligible.  Thus the contract poorly explains the observations.
non-zero g_JT couples O_K^Q ↔ q_Q

question: A material displays an octupolar (K = 3) hidden order at T_o ≈ 60 K accompanied by a cooperative E_g distortion of 0.02 Å.  The linear Jahn–Teller constant is large, g_JT ≈ 40 meV Å⁻¹. question_type: Octupolar order with strong JT coupling
gold_trace:
Although a strong distortion with sizeable g_JT is present, the primary order parameter is an odd-parity octupole which, by the contract’s mechanism, should not couple linearly to lattice modes.  The observed correlation therefore only partially aligns (perhaps via a secondary quadrupole), so consistency is low.
g_JT couples even-parity O_2 to q
octupolar (odd-parity) order → no direct JT coupling in contract
large distortion coincident with octupolar order → unexplained

In this case the observed order is an octupolar (K = 3) order – which is odd under parity – yet it is accompanied by a large E_g distortion and a very big g_{JT} value. paramagnetic DFT+HI → unreliable Σ(ω)

question: An FT-HI calculation on a Mott insulator begins from a spin-polarized DFT+U reference that already breaks time-reversal symmetry. Starting from an already symmetry-broken potential violates this premise, so the resulting odd couplings are likely artefacts.  Credibility is therefore low.
paramagnetic DFT+HI → time-reversal symmetry
symmetry → IEI blocks with certain zeros
spin-polarized start breaks symmetry → artificial off-blocks
observed dipole–quadrupole coupling → likely unphysical
pred_trace: FT-HI in Contract 10-3 relies on starting from an unbroken symmetry (time-reversal symmetric paramagnetic) reference so that the extracted exchange matrix reflects the true multipolar physics. question: A DFT+DMFT Bethe–Salpeter study finds that χ_1(q=0) (dipolar) diverges at 40 K while χ_2 and χ_3 remain finite.  Neutron scattering confirms ferromagnetic ordering. divergence of χ_1 → dipolar instability
dipolar order ↔ visible to neutron probes
contract expects χ_K (K>1) divergence for hidden order

question: To save time, a calculation replaces the full vertex in the Bethe–Salpeter equation with χ₀, obtaining a peak but no divergence in χ_2(q) even though resonant x-ray scattering detects quadrupolar order below 25 K. Omitting the vertex breaks this cause-effect link, so the absence of divergence is an artefact of the approximation, not a failure of the hypothesis.  Consistency is therefore reduced but not zero.
full vertex inclusion → accurate χ_K(q)
divergence of χ_2 → predicts quadrupolar order

In this case, the approximate treatment using only χ₀ fails to show a divergence, even though resonant x-ray scattering confirms quadrupolar order. Thus, despite the numerical deficiency caused by neglecting the full vertex, the contract remains mostly compatible with the physical reality (rated around 0.8).
